001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008
009import java.util.Random;
010
011/**
012 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
013 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
014 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
015 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
016 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
017 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components (though because of
018 * what colorful does, A and B should be multiplied by 2).
019 * <br>
020 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
021 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
022 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
023 */
024public class ColorTools {
025        /**
026         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
027         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
028         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
029         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
030         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
031         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
032         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
033         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
034         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
035         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
036         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
037         * <br>
038         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
039         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
040         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
041         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
042         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
043         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
044         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
045         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
046         *
047         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
048         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
049         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
050         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
051         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
052         */
053        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
054                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
055                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
056        }
057
058
059        /**
060         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
061         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. It
062         * correctly returns negative results when given negative inputs.
063         * <br>
064         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
065         * distributed between -512 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
066         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
067         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
068         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
069         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
070         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
071         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
072         * <br>
073         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
074         * @param x any finite float to find the cube root of
075         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
076         */
077        private static float cbrt(float x) {
078                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
079                final int sign = ix & 0x80000000;
080                ix &= 0x7FFFFFFF;
081                final float x0 = x;
082                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
083                ix += (ix>>>4);
084                ix = ix + (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0 | sign;
085                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
086                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
087                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
088                return x;
089        }
090
091        /**
092         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
093         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
094         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
095         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
096         */
097        private static float cube(final float x) {
098                return x * x * x;
099        }
100
101        /**
102         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
103         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
104         * @return a linear version of component
105         */
106        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
107                return component * component;
108        }
109
110        /**
111         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
112         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
113         * @return a non-linear version of component
114         */
115        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
116                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
117        }
118
119
120        /**
121         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
122         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
123         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
124         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
125         */
126        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
127        {
128                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
129                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
130                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
131                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
132                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
133                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
134                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
135                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
136                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
137                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
138                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
139        }
140
141        /**
142         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
143         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
144         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
145         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
146         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
147         */
148        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
149        {
150                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
151                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
152                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
153                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
154                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
155                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
156                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
157                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
158                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
159                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
160                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
161        }
162        /**
163         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
164         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
165         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
166         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
167         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
168         */
169        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
170        {
171                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
172                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
173                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
174                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
175                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
176                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
177                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
178                editing.r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
179                editing.g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
180                editing.b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
181                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
182                return editing.clamp();
183        }
184
185        /**
186         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
187         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
188         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
189         */
190        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
191                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
192                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
193                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
194
195                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
196                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
197                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
198
199                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
200                                      MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
201                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
202                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
203                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
204        }
205
206        /**
207         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
208         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
209         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
210         */
211        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
212                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
213                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
214                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
215                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
216                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
217                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
218                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
219                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
220                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
221                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
222                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
223                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
224        }
225
226        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
227        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
228        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
229        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
230
231        /**
232         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
233         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
234         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
235         */
236        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
237                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
238                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
239                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
240                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
241                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
242                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
243                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
244                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
245                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
246                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
247                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
248        }
249
250        /**
251         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
252         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
253         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
254         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
255         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
256         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
257         */
258        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
259                r = forwardGamma(r);
260                g = forwardGamma(g);
261                b = forwardGamma(b);
262                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
263                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
264                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
265                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
266                                          MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
267                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
268                                                | MathUtils.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
269                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
270        }
271
272        /**
273         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
274         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
275         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
276         */
277        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
278        {
279                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
280                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
281                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
282                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
283                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
284                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
285                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
286                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
287        }
288
289        /**
290         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
291         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
292         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
293         */
294        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
295        {
296                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
297                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
298                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
299                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
300                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
301                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
302                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
303                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
304        }
305
306        /**
307         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
308         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
309         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
310         */
311        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
312        {
313                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
314                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
315                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
316                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
317                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
318                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
319                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
320                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
321        }
322
323        /**
324         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
325         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
326         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
327         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
328         */
329        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
330        {
331                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
332        }
333
334        /**
335         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
336         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
337         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
338         */
339        public static float red(final float encoded)
340        {
341                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
342                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
343                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
344                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
345                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
346                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
347                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
348                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
349        }
350
351        /**
352         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
353         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
354         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
355         */
356        public static float green(final float encoded)
357        {
358                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
359                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
360                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
361                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
362                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
363                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
364                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
365                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
366        }
367
368        /**
369         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
370         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
371         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
372         */
373        public static float blue(final float encoded)
374        {
375                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
376                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
377                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
378                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
379                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
380                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
381                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
382                return reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
383        }
384
385        /**
386         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
387         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
388         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
389         */
390        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
391        {
392                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
393        }
394
395        /**
396         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
397         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
398         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
399         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
400         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
401         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
402         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
403         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
404         *
405         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
406         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
407         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
408         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
409         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
410         */
411        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
412                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
413                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
414                } else {
415                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
416                }
417        }
418
419        /**
420         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
421         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
422         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
423         */
424        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
425                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
426                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
427                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
428                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
429                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
430                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
431                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
432                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
433                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
434                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
435                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
436                float x, y, w;
437                if(g < b) {
438                        x = b;
439                        y = g;
440                }
441                else {
442                        x = g;
443                        y = b;
444                }
445                if(r < x) {
446                        w = r;
447                }
448                else {
449                        w = x;
450                        x = r;
451                }
452                return x - Math.min(w, y);
453//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
454//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
455//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
456        }
457
458        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
459                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
460                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
461                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
462                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
463                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
464                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
465                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
466                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
467                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
468                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
469                float x, y, w;
470                if(g < b) {
471                        x = b;
472                        y = g;
473                }
474                else {
475                        x = g;
476                        y = b;
477                }
478                if(r < x) {
479                        w = r;
480                }
481                else {
482                        w = x;
483                        x = r;
484                }
485                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
486                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
487        }
488
489        /**
490         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
491         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
492         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
493         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
494         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
495         */
496        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
497                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
498                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
499                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
500                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
501                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
502                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
503                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
504                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
505                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
506                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
507                float x, y, z, w;
508                if(g < b) {
509                        x = b;
510                        y = g;
511                        z = -1f;
512                        w = 2f / 3f;
513                }
514                else {
515                        x = g;
516                        y = b;
517                        z = 0f;
518                        w = -1f / 3f;
519                }
520                if(r < x) {
521                        z = w;
522                        w = r;
523                }
524                else {
525                        w = x;
526                        x = r;
527                }
528                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
529                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
530        }
531
532        /**
533         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
534         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
535         *
536         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
537         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
538         */
539        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
540        {
541                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
542        }
543
544        /**
545         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
546         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
547         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
548         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
549         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
550         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
551         */
552        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
553        {
554                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
555        }
556
557        /**
558         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
559         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
560         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
561         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
562         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
563         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
564         */
565        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
566        {
567                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
568        }
569
570        /**
571         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, value, and
572         * opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Takes floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue,
573         * saturation, value, and opacity; these can be between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or
574         * encoded color with methods like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is
575         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
576         * value, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
577         * <br>
578         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
579         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
580         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
581         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
582         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
583         *
584         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
585         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
586         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
587         * @param value      -1f to 1f, the value/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
588         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
589         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
590         */
591        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float value, float opacity) {
592                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
593                final float L = MathUtils.clamp(value + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f, 1f);
594                opacity = MathUtils.clamp(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f, 1f);
595                if (L <= 0.001f)
596                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
597                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
598                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
599                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
600                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
601                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
602                final float r = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
603                final float g = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
604                final float b = reverseGamma(MathUtils.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
605                float x, y, z, w;
606                if(g < b) {
607                        x = b;
608                        y = g;
609                        z = -1f;
610                        w = 2f / 3f;
611                }
612                else {
613                        x = g;
614                        y = b;
615                        z = 0f;
616                        w = -1f / 3f;
617                }
618                if(r < x) {
619                        z = w;
620                        w = r;
621                }
622                else {
623                        w = x;
624                        x = r;
625                }
626                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
627                float hue2 = Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
628                float sat2 = (x - L) / (Math.min(L, 1f - L) + 1e-10f);
629                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue2 + hue + 1 - (int)(hue2 + hue + 1), MathUtils.clamp(saturation + sat2, 0f, 1f), L, opacity));
630        }
631
632        /**
633         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
634         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
635         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
636         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
637         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
638         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
639         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
640         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
641         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
642         */
643        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
644                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
645                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
646        }
647
648        /**
649         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
650         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
651         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
652         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
653         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
654         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
655         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
656         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
657         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
658         */
659        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
660                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
661                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
662        }
663
664        /**
665         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
666         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
667         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
668         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
669         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
670         * alpha and L of start as-is.
671         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
672         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
673         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
674         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
675         */
676        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
677                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
678                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
679        }
680
681        /**
682         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
683         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
684         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
685         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
686         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
687         * L of start as-is.
688         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
689         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
690         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
691         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
692         */
693        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
694                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
695                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
696        }
697
698        /**
699         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
700         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
701         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
702         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
703         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
704         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
705         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
706         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
707         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
708         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
709         */
710        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
711                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
712                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
713        }
714
715        /**
716         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
717         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
718         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
719         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
720         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
721         * alpha and L of start as-is.
722         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
723         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
724         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
725         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
726         */
727        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
728                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
729                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
730        }
731
732        /**
733         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
734         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
735         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
736         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
737         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
738         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
739         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
740         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
741         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
742         */
743        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
744                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
745                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
746        }
747
748        /**
749         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
750         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
751         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
752         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
753         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
754         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
755         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
756         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
757         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
758         */
759        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
760                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
761                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
762        }
763
764        /**
765         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
766         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
767         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
768         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
769         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
770         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
771         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
772         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
773         */
774        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
775                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
776                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
777                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
778                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
779                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
780        }
781
782        /**
783         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
784         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
785         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only A and B, but higher values for
786         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
787         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change L somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
788         * then L won't change; alpha never changes.
789         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
790         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
791         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
792         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
793         */
794        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
795                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
796                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
797                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
798                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
799                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
800        }
801
802
803        /**
804         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
805         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
806         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
807         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
808         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
809         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
810         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
811         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
812         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
813         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
814         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
815         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
816         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
817         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
818         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
819         */
820        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
821        {
822                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
823                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
824                                L = (bits & 0xff),
825                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
826                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
827                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
828                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
829                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
830                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
831                        return mainColor;
832                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
833        }
834
835        /**
836         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
837         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
838         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
839         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
840         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
841         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
842         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
843         */
844        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
845                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
846                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
847                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
848                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
849                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
850                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
851                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
852        }
853
854        /**
855         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
856         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
857         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
858         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
859         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
860         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
861         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
862         * but only internally for measuring distance).
863         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
864         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
865         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
866         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
867         */
868        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
869                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
870                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
871                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
872                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
873                final float limit = variance * variance;
874                float dist, x, y, z;
875                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
876                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
877                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
878                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
879                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
880                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
881                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
882                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
883                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
884                }
885                return color;
886        }
887
888        /**
889         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
890         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
891         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
892         */
893        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
894        {
895                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
896                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
897                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
898                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
899                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
900                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
901                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
902
903                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
904                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
905                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
906                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
907                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
908                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
909        }
910        /**
911         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
912         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
913         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
914         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
915         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
916         */
917        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
918        {
919                A = (A - 0.5f) * 2f;
920                B = (B - 0.5f) * 2f;
921                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
922                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
923                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
924
925                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
926//              if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) {
927//                      System.out.println("r out of gamut: " + r);
928//                      return false;
929//              }
930                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
931                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
932//              if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) {
933//                      System.out.println("g out of gamut: " + g);
934//                      return false;
935//              }
936                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
937                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
938//              if(b < 0f || b > 1.0f) {
939//                      System.out.println("b out of gamut: " + b);
940//                      return false;
941//              }
942//              return true;
943                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
944        }
945
946        /**
947         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
948         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
949         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
950         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
951         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
952         */
953        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
954                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
955                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
956                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
957                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
958                float L2 = L, A2 = A, B2 = B;
959                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
960                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
961                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
962                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
963
964                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
965                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
966                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
967                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
968                                break;
969                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
970                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
971                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
972                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
973                }
974                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
975        }
976
977        /**
978         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
979         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
980         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
981         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
982         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
983         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
984         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
985         */
986        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
987                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
988        }
989        /**
990         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
991         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
992         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
993         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
994         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
995         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
996         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
997         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
998         */
999        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1000                float L2 = L = MathUtils.clamp(L, 0f, 1f);
1001                float A2 = A = MathUtils.clamp((A - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
1002                float B2 = B = MathUtils.clamp((B - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
1003                alpha = MathUtils.clamp(alpha, 0f, 1f);
1004                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1005                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
1006                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
1007                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
1008
1009                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
1010                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
1011                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
1012                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1013                                break;
1014                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1015                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
1016                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
1017                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
1018                }
1019                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1020        }
1021
1022        /**
1023         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1024         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1025         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1026         */
1027        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1028                float L = random.nextFloat();
1029                float A = random.nextFloat();
1030                float B = random.nextFloat();
1031                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1032                        L = random.nextFloat();
1033                        A = random.nextFloat();
1034                        B = random.nextFloat();
1035                }
1036                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1037        }
1038}
